content: The "Trademark Amendments Act of 1999" may be cited as the short title. Dilution can be used as grounds for opposition and cancellation. The "Trademark Amendments Act of 1999" allows for refusal of registration and cancellation of marks causing dilution under section 43(c). Opposition can be based on dilution under section 43(c). The Trademark Amendments Act of 1999 allows for refusal of registration and cancellation of marks causing dilution under section 43(c), including as a result of dilution under section 43(c) after "principal register," "damaged," and "register." SEC. 3. REMEDIES IN CASES OF DILUTION OF FAMOUS MARKS. Injunctions and damages related to violations under sections 43(a) and 43(c) of the Trademark Act of 1946 are amended. Destruction of articles in cases of violations under section 43(a) or willful violations under section 43(c) is also addressed. Injunctions and damages for violations under sections 43(a) and 43(c) of the Trademark Act of 1946 are amended to include willful violations under section 43(c). SEC. 4. LIABILITY OF GOVERNMENTS FOR TRADEMARK INFRINGEMENT AND DILUTION. Section 32 of the Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include the United States, its agencies, individuals, firms, corporations, and States in civil actions related to trademark infringement. The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include States, officers, and employees under its provisions, waiving sovereign immunity for the United States and its agencies in cases of trademark violations. The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to waive sovereign immunity for States, officers, and employees in cases of trademark violations, including governmental or nongovernmental entities. The Trademark Act of 1946 is amended to include the United States, its agencies, and individuals acting on its behalf under the definition of "person" subject to the provisions of the Act. SEC. 5. CIVIL ACTIONS FOR TRADE DRESS INFRINGEMENT. Amends Section 43(a) of the Trademark Act of 1946 to require proof of non-functionality in civil actions for trade dress infringement. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AMENDMENTS. Amends the Trademark Act of 1946 by making technical changes to the assignment of marks and clerical amendments to replace "trade-marks" with "trademarks." The Association to Preserve the Authenticity of Musical Groups aims to educate the public on performing groups' history and performers. The Association has the sole right to its certification mark and sets standards for entertainers using it, including having original group members and truthful advertising.
